title: Enabling multichannel participation through ict adaptations
abstract: Participatory budgeting (PB) represents one of the most successful civic innovations of the last quarter-century. At a time when voter turnout in Europe is lagging and public institutions struggle to maintain trust and legitimacy within a framework of growing budgetary cuts, PB has proved itself to be a powerful tool for citizens to join in the essential tasks of governing, not only as voters but also as decision-makers themselves. EMPATIA aims at producing the first ICT platform capable of fully encompassing both the decision-making cycle and the implementation cycle of PB whose integration is considered indispensable by literature as the main driver of the self-sustainability process. It will harness the collaborative power of ICT networks applied to PB, seeking to radically enhance the inclusiveness and impact of PB processes, enabling citizens, individually and collectively, to take deliberate and informed action for the public good. This will lower barriers to information and participation, deepening citizen engagement and trust in public institutions, collaborating alongside them to make their communities more sustainable. EMPATIA consists of multidisciplinary consortium, with expertise in adjacent fields – research and implementation of participatory and voting processes, ICT integration, evaluation of technological and societal impacts among others – that will include in its activities the implementation of three distinct PB Pilots, with citizens from the municipalities of Lisbon (Portugal), Ričany (Czech Republic) and Bonn (Germany), allowing a thorough analysis and validation of the EMPATIA platform.

motivations: Low voter turnout and declining trust in public institutions in Europe necessitate innovative approaches to civic engagement.
Existing participatory budgeting (PB) processes face limitations in inclusiveness and sustainability due to inadequate integration of decision-making and implementation cycles.
objectives: Develop an ICT platform that integrates the decision-making and implementation cycles of participatory budgeting to enhance its inclusiveness and impact.
Harness the collaborative power of ICT networks to facilitate informed citizen participation and collective action for the public good.
Lower barriers to information and participation, thereby deepening citizen engagement and trust in public institutions.
methods: Design and implement an ICT platform for participatory budgeting that integrates decision-making and implementation cycles.
Conduct three pilot projects in distinct municipalities (Lisbon, Ričany, and Bonn) to test and validate the EMPATIA platform.
Leverage a multidisciplinary consortium with expertise in participatory processes, ICT integration, and impact evaluation to ensure the platform's effectiveness.
results: Enhance the inclusiveness and sustainability of participatory budgeting processes through ICT-enabled citizen engagement.
Increase citizen participation and trust in public institutions by providing accessible information and opportunities for collective action.
Contribute to more sustainable communities through collaborative decision-making and implementation of participatory budgeting initiatives.
